projects.title: Invictus BCI Collaboration
projects.info: Our Electrical team is currently working with the startup Invictus BCI to improve the EMG armband of their prosthetic hand model. To do this, the team is developing a prototype that will interpret muscle signals at lower costs.

projects.title: Eikufuba Educational Project
projects.info: Ekifuba Educational Program is a collaboration with Rose Academies and is a simple, easy to understand, innovative approach to breaking barriers of stigma, fear, myths, and misconceptions of tuberculosis. Our primary goal is to address the lack of understanding about TB and improve knowledge of the disease, symptoms, prevention, and treatment so that the occurrence of TB can be reduced substantially. The program will run on an Android table that has been successfully used as an education tool since its introduction into Uganda’s rural communities in 2018. The program runs offline internet, features simple graphics and limited text as the lesson is taught in the local dialect by a Rose Uganda Fellow. Workshops are taught in a group setting, with lessons that improve understanding of TB transmission, prevention through healthy choices, nutrition, and sanitation, and early diagnosis and treatment.

projects.title: First Opinion
projects.info: This project is a collaboration with an early phase start-up called First Opinion that seeks to provide a low-cost resource for accurate medical information in India. This is the business team’s first official collaboration in a while, featuring marketing, biz dev, and web dev services.

projects.title: Calmer Project
projects.info: Our Integrative Design and Electrical teams are currently developing a device to aid pain management for infants in the NICU, working with Dr. Liisa Holsti at B.C. Children's Hospital. The teams are modifying Holsti’s existing Calmer design to optimize it for uptake in lower-and-middle-income countries.
projects.info_long:
Worldwide, over 15 million infants are born preterm. A current challenge that the neonatal healthcare community faces today is pain management for preterm infants in Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICU). It is well established that early exposure to pain in preterm infants is associated with negative effects on neurodevelopmental outcomes. However, in lower- and middle-income countries, there is a distinct shortage of pain medication available. One common pain management method is the Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) technique, which involves holding an infant in an upright position on the infant caretaker’s bare chest for long periods of time. However, the KMC technique is not suitable for use because caretakers are unable to use it during pain-inducing procedures. 
 To address this challenge, researchers at the University of British Columbia under the leadership of Dr. Liisa Holsti developed the Calmer device, a complex medical instrument that simulates Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) to manage premature infants’ pain in the NICU. Clinical trials have found that the Calmer device provides the same level of pain management for premature infants as human contact using the KMC technique by replicating a heartbeat sound, using a heated and textured surface, and mimicking a breathing motion. Clinical trials have found that the Calmer device provides the same level of pain management for premature infants as another human touch strategy called facilitated tucking by replicating a heartbeat sound, using a skin-like surface, and mimicking a breathing motion. 
 The current Calmer device is too expensive and energy-demanding for effective utilization in low and middle-income countries. Furthermore, the current Calmer device isn’t designed for dust protection and easy transport. Thus, our Integrative Design and Electrical subteams worked with Dr. Holsti to redesign the Calmer device for usage in these countries. 
 Our device simulates a breathing motion by lifting an acrylic platform up to 0.5” with a camshaft. Metal rods that are affixed to the mobile platform assure that the platform ascends and descends smoothly. This design also incorporates additional features meant to increase the stability of the prototype and breathing motion. These include multiple PLA supports in the middle and the corners of the device to support the platforms, PLA camshaft supports with ball bearings to prevent the camshaft from bending, and a fixed acrylic platform between the moving platform and supports. The camshaft in our device is powered by a motor utilizing an external power source. The device also contains a speaker that plays the sound of a heartbeat, which can be adjusted for speed and volume by using dials. This component is also electronically powered.

projects.title: Assistive Glasses
projects.info: This multi-team project seeks to build a data collection app that will ultimately serve a Ml model powering glasses for low vision patients that enables them to see through real time image detection. This is in collaboration with the Avarind Eye Care System in India that manufactures specialty eye care equipment. The team works directly with a Cornell professor and PhD student who act as a medium between EWH and the glasses company.
projects.info_long: This multi-team project seeks to build a data collection app that will ultimately serve a Ml model powering glasses for low vision patients that enables them to see through real time image detection. This is in collaboration with the Avarind Eye Care System in India that manufactures specialty eye care equipment. The team works directly with a Cornell professor and PhD student who act as a medium between EWH and the glasses company.

projects.title: Management Sciences for Health Collaboration
projects.info: This newly formed subteam is developing an automated web-scraper to collect job and funding information from target sites such as ThinkWell, UNICEF, WHO, Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, etc.
projects.info_long:
Over the course of a year, one of two software subteams collaborated with Management Sciences for Health (MSH), a global, advisory non-profit organization that strengthens health systems. Specifically, they joined MSH under Dr. Christian Suharlim, a Senior Technical Advisor for Global Health Systems Innovation and the Director of Public Affairs for the Immunization Economics Community of Practice. 
 During their internship with MSH, the team focused on building an automated opportunities dashboard that utilized web-scraping technologies to create a platform for health economists and immunization professionals to collaborate. This dashboard aims to consolidate job and funding opportunities from major ImmunizationEconomics.org partners and sponsors including but not limited to the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Johns Hopkins, and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. In addition, the team wrote and sought publication for a commentary centered around the global health labor force movement, especially within the era of COVID-19.

projects.title: Health Friend
projects.info: Currently, menstrual health is considered very taboo in low-resource communities in India. The software subteam is partnering with Barefoot College to design and implement an educational game with an engaging story-line and rich visuals to teach women about their bodies from the safety of their own homes.
projects.info_long:
Health Friend is a menstrual health education game designed for women aged between 15-50 in rural India, specifically those with low literacy or little to no prior experience with tech. While menstrual health and hygiene are still taboo in many low-resource communities in India, Health Friend provides women an informative, transparent, and narrative-driven menstrual health education experience. 
 Collaborators at Barefoot College informed the team that when they show videos to their students, they feel that the information is much easier to learn than with print materials, especially when it comes to the complex biological processes involved with women’s health. The game is written with Kivy, an open-source Python library. With an engaging storyline and interactive game features, the user is able to be learning while enjoying the story. At the end of each chapter, users will also be required to complete assessment modules to unlock the next chapter. There are 10 chapters covering different topics, such as mensuration, health services, and contraception. The game analytics of the quiz modules are exported to the collaborators at Barefoot College to further help them improve their menstrual health curriculum. Teachers have the ability to create their own accounts and build their student roster for their classrooms on the website. 
 Health Friend has been passed off to our collaborators at Barefoot College for use. It’s also available on the Google Play Store.

projects.title: tVNS
projects.info: The electrical team collaborated with a neurostimulation company to develop a mechanism for measuring heart rate variability at the auricular region during simultaneous usage of the company’s tVNS device.
projects.info_long:
This project involved collaboration with a neurostimulation company that develops devices to alleviate symptoms from conditions such as depression, cardiac fibrillation, and epilepsy by utilizing vagus nerve stimulation. Our objective was to develop a mechanism for measuring heart rate variability at the auricular region during simultaneous usage of the company’s tVNS device. The collaborator supplied the first model of a tVNS device for comparison and compatibility with our “prototype” heart rate variability sensor. We performed research to identify a cost-effective heart rate sensor and an accurate gold standard device for data verification, and developed Arduino code implementing the RMSSD (root mean square of successive differences) algorithm for real-time heart rate variability calculations.
 The next steps involved verifying the accuracy of our device and algorithm prototype in controlled trials. We performed data collection and analysis using different anatomical locations for extracting heart rate signals (in beats per minute), evaluating multiple methods for securely fitting the prototype. Additionally, we checked for interference between our prototype and the collaborator’s device. 
 Finally, we rigorously verified our prototype through analysis of post-processing outlier data and analysis of other potential sources of measurement errors. We concluded that the collaborator’s device did not interfere with the accuracy of our prototype. Since photoplethysmography (PPG) measurement requires tight contact, further work will be necessary to design a flexible and possibly customizable housing for the prototype that fits snugly against the curvature of the concha in a variety of subjects. Due to logistical complications of COVID-19, later stages of testing were canceled and we advise that our prototype should be further verified with a medical-grade EKG sensor before being adapted and applied to a consumer medical device.  After final verification and integration, the prototype can be utilized to track HRV in conjunction with the collaborator’s device.

projects.title: Kijenzi Projects
projects.info: The Integrative Design Subteam completed 3D-printable designs for an Assistive Sock Aid device and Arm Supinator/Pronator device to be distributed by Kijenzi, a nonprofit that 3D prints medical devices in under resourced communities.
projects.info_long:
The Integrative Design Subteam completed 3D-printable designs to be used by Kijenzi, a nonprofit that 3-D prints medical devices in under-resourced communities. The Assistive Sock Aid and Arm Supinator/Pronator designs were solutions in order to meet the needs of occupational therapy patients in Sub-Saharan Africa. Both designs are 3D-printable and minimize the need for additional material, thus creating cost-effective and efficient solutions.
 The Assistive Sock Aid device, which helps a patient who cannot bend their spine to place a sock on their foot, went through many iterations of design beginning with a prototype made out of a plastic water bottle. Testing was able to occur on the second iteration design which was 3D printed and the results surfaced the need for the device to be thinner, have a mechanism to hold the sock in a more secure manner, and have lips that could be threaded. Ultimately, the most optimal design was composed of a tapered semi-cylindrical tube with a lip at the top that allowed for the threading of twine, a hook on the back of the device to hold the sock, and holes for the final tying of twine. 
 The Arm Supinator/Pronator device, which helps nurse and strengthen a patient's injured shoulder through the repeated motion of pronation and supination, began with an initial design of a wheel with a center handle that could be used to twist the wheel back and forward. Although testing of the second iteration was supposed to occur with a 3D-printed prototype due to COVID-19 that was not possible. As a result, finite element analysis (FEA) on Fusion 360 was used to determine structural weak points in the design. In the end, the most optimal design attempted to fix these weak points and was composed of a wheel that could attach to the wall through a mount, had a handle in the middle with holes for grip strength, and had weights that could be added for increased resistance during use.

projects.title: INDAGO
projects.info: The INDAGO subteam designed an online tool to streamline the FDA approval process for entering the clinical trial phase of new drug development. This tool allowed researchers to create and manage their Investigational New Drug Application (IND) while receiving tailored advice through a computerized support system.
projects.info_long:
The INDAGO subteam designed an interface to streamline the FDA approval process for researchers preparing to enter the clinical trial phase of new drug development. 
 INDAGO is an online tool designed to streamline the FDA approval process for researchers preparing to enter the clinical trial phase of new drug development. Similar to a college application or TurboTax, it walks users through the steps to submit the Investigational New Drug Application (IND) and offers various tools to facilitate the process. It allows users to create and manage their applications while accessing tailored advice through a computerized support system that unites FDA guidelines with institutional and third-party guidance. The implications of this project are that new, potentially life-saving medications can be tested and made available for use in a more efficient manner. 
 This project was initiated in early 2019 by a Cornell Engineering World Health (EWH) member who worked with an early-stage startup in the pharmaceutical industry and saw many issues when it came to navigating the path toward clinical trials. In creating INDAGO, he hoped to mitigate the challenges researchers face when proceeding to clinical trials. More specifically, these challenges surround understanding and successfully submitting pertinent documentation, such as the Investigational New Drug Application (IND) and New Drug Application (NDA). 
 Finding a potential solution to these problems could organize and simplify this process, which is what INDAGO aims to do.

projects.title: Rex
projects.info: Rex is an app empowering patients and doctors with a simple solution for tracking long-term medical conditions.
projects.info_long:
Rex is an app empowering patients and doctors with a simple solution for tracking long-term medical conditions. Patients utilize the app to record their symptoms as they are happening. Doctors then use this reliable information to aid in treatment and diagnosis. The app also lets patients create reminders for them to take their medication. 
 The application features symptom tracking including fast symptom logging and the ability to review past symptom history. It also includes medication controls to easily organize medications by keeping track of them, customizing push notifications as reminders, and calendar views to access progress. Lastly, it features a user-focused interface with simple visualizations and controls, not requiring account registration. 
 Our simple-to-use application encourages patients to be more proactive in logging their conditions and enables doctors to easily access their progress. The app was handed off to a doctor at Weill Cornell for testing.

projects.title: Incinerator
projects.info: The Integrative Design subteam partnered with a nonprofit in India called Barefoot College to develop a waste incinerator: an environmental alternative for women disposing of menstrual waste items.
projects.info_long:
The Integrative Design partnered with a nonprofit in India called Barefoot College to develop an environmental alternative to waste removal. The Incinerator iis a solution developed for Barefoot College in order to meet the needs of women in Rajasthan, India. Three solutions were first proposed in order to create a clean-energy and low-cost menstrual waste disposal system. The activated charcoal filter design focused on filtering out harmful toxins in the smoke produced while burning menstrual waste by adding the activated charcoal filter to a pre-existing mudka. The fresnel lens design aimed to incinerate the menstrual pads by using a fresnel lens that concentrated sunlight onto the pads in order to begin combustion. Lastly, the solar cooker design looked at once again harnessing the power of sunlight in order to then incinerate the pads.
 This design was not prototyped or tested due to time constraints and feasibility. After prototyping the activated charcoal design and testing it with the Wynd Air Quality Tracker it was found that the design did not seem effective in reducing the number of toxins being produced by the mudka. However, after testing the fresnel lens design in Florida it was found that this design allowed for simple combustion by having the Fresnel lens effectively concentrate sunlight to an area and begin combustion around the same time each day. Ultimately, the fresnel lens design was deemed the most successful and optimal design created.

projects.title: Grip Sensor Project
projects.info: The electrical subteam partnered with the National Institute of Health (NIH) to build a patient grip device that could be used for opioid addiction research.
projects.info_long:
The electrical subteam partnered with the National Institute of Health (NIH) to build a device that could be used for opioid addiction research. NIH requested that we build a device that could take information on the force of a patient's grip over time for use in collecting data. We built a small, hollow, hand-held cylinder with three force-sensitive resistors connected to an internal Arduino that could track the average force applied to the device based on a set of voltage dividers. This data was transmitted via Bluetooth to an external computer. We used an Arduino script on the Adafruit Feather board and a python script for the receiving computer where we saved the data in a CSV. 
 Our initial prototype ran on a small internal battery; however, when we tested it this semester, we realized the battery ran out of power within about ten minutes, which wasn’t practical for lab use. We eliminated the battery, making it power off a USB connection to a computer instead, allowing for prolonged use. 
 An additional capability to our final iteration was serial output via USB, which was integrated into the existing python script. This feature ensured that data could be transmitted in the case that the computers used didn’t have Bluetooth capability. The serial output transmits the average of the force-sensitive resistor values over time, which is the same as the data transmitted by Bluetooth.

projects.title: Solar Powered Heater
projects.info: The Integrative Design subteam partnered with SAWA, a nonprofit working in  refugee camps in Lebanon, to help design a heating device to keep refugees warm using renewable energy.
projects.info_long:
The goal for this solar-powered heating system was to develop a cost-effective, energy-efficient prototype temperature mediation system that would provide heat to people living in refugee camps, primarily those in Syria and Lebanon. This project was in collaboration with SAWA for Development & Aid, a Civil Society Organization. SAWA works directly to support the needs of refugees in Syria and Lebanon. Specifically, SAWA has created programs that target relief for refugees by providing shelter, energy, food, healthcare, and education. Concern regarding the way refugees were keeping warm in the camps—by burning tires, plastic, trash, etc in plastic barrels releasing toxins into the air and subsequently, living in and breathing those toxins in—prompted the need for a more efficient and non-toxic heating mechanism. 
 The proposed heating system involves a solar collector powered by a battery that is charged by a PV cell. A solar charge controller regulates the charging and discharging of the battery and regulates delivery to the load. The heat generated by the solar collector is carried in the water-based mixture through a series of pipes to the kotatsu table. The heated water mixture is circulated into a cylindrical container filled with sand, held above a mesh through which the water, but not the sand, would flow through. The water is then funneled into piping that leads back to the solar collector, thus creating a closed system for the water-based mixture. The reasoning behind this sand-filled container was as follows: hot water would heat the sand and this heat would radiate through the metal cylindrical container and warm the area under the table. This area is closed off from the outside by a large duvet held down by the tabletop. 
 Testing for the device took place at Cornell University. The data collected from the testing period gauged the prototype’s success—this was determined from the longevity of the system being able to generate heat, temperature increase in the underside of the table, etc. Designs were passed to the collaborators upon completion.

projects.title: Infant Jaundice Therapy
projects.info: The team designed a low-cost, lightweight device to treat Jaundice in newborn babies through phototherapy.
projects.info_long:
Approximately 50 percent of term newborns and 80 percent of preterm newborns develop jaundice, yellow discoloration of a baby's skin and eyes. Approximately 5 to 10 percent of infant mortality in developing countries is caused by jaundice complications. Jaundice is caused by elevated levels of bilirubin, and 6 million babies a year are at risk for cerebral palsy, blindness, deafness, cognitive damage, and death if left untreated. The cure for jaundice is phototherapy or blue light. However, current solutions, including traditional halogen lamps and modern LED devices, are often not portable and place multiple babies in one device, which  increases the risks of spreading infection and inconsistent treatment.
 The final design by Cornell EWH drew inspiration from collapsible tents and foldable foam boxes and prioritized portability, longevity, electronic embeddability, low cost, ease of use, and feasibility. After consulting with Dr. Srisatish Devapatla at Cayuga Medical Center, the team finalized a lightweight, foldable design with a 180 degree roll top. The device was embedded with blue LED lights in the top struts and bottom cushion and made of waterproof fabric and bean bags. Preliminary performance was collected by the team on the device’s effectiveness.

projects.title: Mycotoxin Filter Table
projects.info: Mycotoxins are metabolites of fungi that contaminate crops, especially in resource-constrained settings. This project developed a low-cost gravity table that small-holder farmers can use to sort and filter mycotoxin-infested crops to produce safe, healthy foods.
projects.info_long:
Mycotoxins, notably aflatoxin and fumonisin, are metabolites of fungi that contaminate staple crops predominantly in resource-limited settings. Due to their immunosuppressive, carcinogenic, and toxic effects, mycotoxins pose a serious threat to human health across the globe. The populations most susceptible to mycotoxin exposure are those living in rural, resource-limited areas, where subsistence farming is common and food insecurity is a pressing issue.
 Cornell Engineering World Health developed a low-cost, effective solution that small-holder farmers can use to sort their crops and provide safe, healthy food for themselves and their communities. This device was a small-scale gravity table constructed with low-cost, durable, and accessible materials. The table was predominantly made of wood, with a mesh deck, a fan to provide airflow, and a vibrating motor. It was designed to be largely portable, with multiple detachable parts that enabled easy transport. The gravity table sorted out mycotoxin-infected corn kernels from healthy kernels on the basis of density differences. Infected kernels are less dense and thus when fed onto a dual-angled vibrating mesh deck, the fan levitates the contaminated kernels into a separate bin from the healthy ones. This device serves as a low resource option for sorting toxins in corn.

projects.title: Forefront Water Monitor
projects.info: The water monitor was a cross-subteam effort to design an automated water quality monitoring system that measures basic characteristics of well water and sends information over long distances.
projects.info_long:
Working with collaborators at global nonprofit Forefront, EWH designed an automated water quality monitoring system to target water safety and cleanliness. Current water wells built by nonprofits are dangerous to use because they are not monitored and evaluated for water cleanliness. EWH’s automated water monitor measures basic characteristics of well water and sends information over long distances. The monitor is either solar, battery, or pump powered. 
 The main components of the device include a collection chamber and an adjacent analysis chamber. The collection chamber siphons a small portion of the water from the well. In the collection chamber, sensors measure aspects such as the temperature, pH, conductivity, turbidity, and ion concentration of the water. Temperature is relevant because pH and conductivity are temperature dependent and thus higher temperatures typically indicate the presence of biologics. pH is monitored because the safe pH range for drinking water is from 6.5 to 8.0. Conductivity is recorded as an indirect measure of water hardness with calcium, magnesium, and sodium concentrations. Lastly, turbidity is relevant as it is a measure of water cloudiness due to particulates and sediment. The sensors are connected to the data acquisition unit located in the analysis chamber. Water exits the collection chamber through an outflow pipe after all the necessary data is acquired. 
The device then sends the collected measurements over a 2G network, and a web dashboard application receive the data updates graphs and other visuals immediately. The dashboard provides various graphic and analytical tools to allow users to find meaningful trends in the data. It additionally notifies users through text or email if it detects any dangerous changes in the water quality. The designs and insights from this project were sent to collaborators at Forefront upon completion.

projects.title: Vaccine Refrigerator
projects.info: The Integrative Design subteam created a passively cooled vaccine refrigerator that could maintain the required low temperature for several hours.
projects.info_long:
It is difficult to transport vaccines between remote villages in low-and-middle-income countries because they can spoil due to warm temperatures. Generally, current storage devices at the time of the project only kept vaccines fresh for a maximum of five days because the cooling process only involved an off-the-shelf cooler with multiple ice packs. However, a vaccine that has not been transported at the correct temperature is ineffective. EWH’s vaccine refrigerator gave people more time to transport vaccines between sites without the fear of ruining the vaccines.
 The idea came from Bill Gates’ “Super Thermos” model, which can cool vaccines for 30 to 60 days depending on temperatures and humidity. For EWH’s vaccine refrigerator model, a cylindrical chamber that holds the physical vaccine is surrounded by layers of insulation that prevents heat loss. The cylindrical structure, which opens from the top, minimizes exposure to the outside air when the fridge is opened. 
The fridge was made of HPMI plastic because the material is durable and has lower thermal conductivity. Aerogel insulation was used for its low conductivity. Members ran multiple tests to examine the reliability and effectiveness of the vaccine refrigerator. For example, temperature retention was tested by inserting temperature probes in various locations of the cooler, such as in the vaccine vials, at the door, and near any light sources. 
Simulations demonstrated that the fridge could hold 138 vaccine doses and maintain a temperature within a 2-8 degree Celsius desired range for 16 hours.

projects.title: Medlife Outreach
projects.info: Cornell Engineering World Health partnered with MedLife International, a nonprofit organization that runs many mobile clinics. Members from EWH traveled to Lima, Peru for eight days, serving local patients and completing several projects while there.
projects.info_long:
Cornell Engineering World Health has actively participated in various outreach activities in order to integrate with local communities and find inspiration for future projects. A few years ago, members of the team traveled to Lima, Peru for eight days where they partnered with MedLife International, a nonprofit organization that runs many mobile clinics. During the trip, the team shadowed health care workers and worked alongside them to serve local patients. They also completed several projects, including building a staircase to help facilitate transportation for the community. Through this eye-opening experience, our members not only grew as individuals through their first-hand exposure to the implementation of global health initiatives, but also helped bring back ideas and stories that guide the future progression of the team. As our team continues to grow, we hope we can continuously build upon these valuable first hand experiences by creating more opportunities to interact with the world.
 Quotes from our alumni: 
 “This experience helped shed light on the actual lifestyle of the people we design products for, along with providing an insider perspective on how a developing community lives and the unique region-specific illnesses it faces.“ - Justin 
 “The experience of visiting and seeing the low resource environment puts context into the work we do back at Cornell. We can put faces to the people we [were] trying to serve; it gave me extra motivation to work and develop a solution having met these people in need.“ - Paul 
“There [was] beautiful, filtered water running in huge pipes through many poor, water-borne-disease-prone communities surrounding Lima, but it only carries the clean water into the rich areas, not stopping for the poor. It made me realize that engineering has to work in conjunction with people and their governments in order to have any effect. Seeing that blatant inefficiency caused by policies has definitely changed the way I will approach engineering problems in the future.“ -Brecken

projects.title: Vital Signs Monitor
projects.info: The Electrical subteam designed a vital signs monitoring device as a resource to assist in providing valuable medical services to low resource communities. The device sends collected information through a radio frequency to a central location known as the “base station“, which relays information between nurse and patient.
projects.info_long:
Many health care systems in low income countries lack the resources to provide sufficient medical services. The World Health Organization estimated that 70% to 96% of medical equipment in these countries is broken, however, many medical facilities do not have the financial capabilities to replace important parts for these existing devices. One such device commonly utilized is a vital signs monitor (VSM), a diagnostic instrument capable of logging a patient’s heart-rate, blood pressure, temperature, and pulse oximetry. 
 The Cornell EWH chapter contacted medical professionals abroad regarding the scarcity of affordable VSMs, and gauged the necessity of such an instrument in evolving healthcare systems. It was determined that a more robust, affordable VSM could serve a much needed medical service. Building upon this idea, Cornell EWH began developing an idea that would later evolve into a more complex system of networked VSMs capable of remotely sharing real-time patient information with medical professionals so as to augment timely medical services. 
 The final device had the ability to send the collected information through a radio frequency to a central location known as the “base station”, which maintained two databases for patient and nurse information. The base station recorded information such as the nurse’s mobile phone number for SMS messaging to facilitate quicker response times if a patient’s health suddenly deteriorates. Along with receiving an SMS message, the VSM indicated the patient’s worsening condition via buzzers and LEDs. Accompanying SMS messaging, a nurse was able to monitor any patient’s status through a web application accessible from any internet-enabled device.

projects.title: Baby Holster
projects.info: In response to the United Nations’ goal to reduce child mortality worldwide by 67% by the year 2015, the team developed an Antimicrobial Baby Holster to minimize the risk of infection in Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) techniques, a low cost neonatal care method used worldwide.
projects.info_long:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is a technique commonly used to assist early childhood development, especially for premature babies. The KMC technique refers to swaddling the baby to the mother’s or father’s chest to emphasize skin-to-skin contact. This contact not only develops the parent-child bond but also imitates the warmer temperatures and environment of the incubation chamber used in NICUs in the western world. This remains a heavily recommended technique for newborns, especially in the developing world. 
 Unfortunately, the KMC technique was not without its limitations. Improperly swaddling  a child can lead to Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) if the child is wrapped too tightly. Furthermore, the swaddling cloth will get dirty over time, leading to heightened infection risks. In response, the team developed the Antimicrobial Baby Holster to minimize the risk of infection in KMC. The baby holster was functionally identical to the swaddling clothes used around the world today, with the added benefit of being antimicrobial. The aloe vera spray coating used to make the cloth antimicrobial was determined to be readily available and could last for a number of wash cycles. By retaining its antimicrobial properties for long periods of time, the holster aims to further reduce infant mortality in line with the Millenium Development Goal.

projects.title: Autologous Blood Transfusion System
projects.info: The Autologous Transfusion System designed by EWH Cornell sought to create a simple handheld, reusable auto-transfusion system that addressed several shortcomings of the other low-cost auto-transfusion systems.
projects.info_long:
Every year, millions of women world-wide suffer from excessive blood loss in cases of ruptured ectopic pregnancies. For instance, hemorrhaging is the leading cause of maternal mortality in Sub-Saharan Africa, with 87% due to ectopic pregnancy ruptures. Women can often lose up to half their blood volume (developing acute anemia) and are usually in desperate need of transfusion. However, in developing nations, there are often insufficient supplies of donor blood due to high frequency of diseases such as HIV/AIDS. 
 Design Innovations for Infants and Mothers Everywhere (DIIME) has attempted to address this problem by developing a device, known as the Hemafuse, which transfers and filters blood using a manual hand-pump method, and then re-transfuses the clean blood into patients. Although this device is simple, clean, and reusable, it fails to make the process less labor intensive, nor does it reduce crowding and chaos in the surgical area. 
 The Autologous Transfusion System designed by EWH Cornell sought to create a simple handheld, reusable auto-transfusion system that addressed several shortcomings of the current Hemafuse device. The proposed transfusion system would be inserted into the patient’s abdomen during surgery and sucked out by a foot pump powered by a hand crank. The foot pump draws the blood through a sterile IV bag with anticoagulant tubing, and anticoagulant is added  to remove and prevent clots, ensuring safe blood storage before transfusion. This blood transfusion process not only stores blood in a sterile environment with anticoagulants but also returns the blood to a patient in a closed loop system. This system, therefore, reduced the risk of transmitting airborne infections and transfusing clots into the patient's body. Moreover, the transfusion system was designed to be a distance away from the operating table to clear surgical space, so the nurse isn’t clumsily extracting and pumping blood out of wounds while near the physicians who are attempting to operate. The designs were provided for resource limited clinics in sub-Saharan Africa as an option to achieve fewer patient complications, lower procedure costs, and decreased mortality rates related to pregnancy.
